section1List.hed: Why Tomato Toast Is the Ultimate Summer Snack
section1List.dek: Because the greatest thing since sliced bread is sliced tomatoes.
section1List.promoHed: The Summer Snack That Beats Avocado Toast
section1List.body:
For years now, [avocado toast](http://www.epicurious.com/ingredients/ultimate-avocado-toast-recipe-article) has ruled our world. At least on Instagram. But is avocado really the most delicious (or photogenic) thing we can put on crispy bread? For a few months every summer, the answer is nobecause who needs avocados when there are ripe, juicy tomatoes around?

[#video: /videos/55ae8ee9a188eea213e60326]||||||

Theres something sacred about tomato toast. The combination of sweet sun-ripened tomatoes, well-toasted bread, and a pinch of salt satisfies on a fundamental level. But that simple, classic recipe is just the beginning. Like its cousin avocado toast, tomato toast is an excellent vehicle for creativity and, with the tomato high season upon us, theres plenty of surplus to experiment with.

As these 13 recipes show, theres a slew of different ways to treat your tomatoes (Grated! Roasted! Pickled! Seared!) and plenty of flavor combinations to spin off of. Armed with a few easy tips, you may just find yourself making tomato toasts every day. Good thing they're easy on the eyes.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ad1a032165ea1779870382]||||||

+++

##Lesson #1: Start with ripe (not refrigerated) tomatoes##

When you're buying tomatoes at the market, look for tomatoes that feel heavy for their size and have unblemished skin. And sniff! Always sniff. A ripe, flavorful tomato will have that unmistakeable tomato-vine scent. 

Keep in mind that most tomatoes are sold a day or two short of peak ripeness (otherwise they wouldn't survive the trip home in your bag). So once you get them home, leave them on the countertop to ripen a bit more. For the love of all that is good and holy, do not refrigerate your tomatoes. Besides turning them mealy, the fridge will make your sweet, innocent tomatoes taste metallic. Buy only what you need for a few days, or invite the neighbors over for a tomato-toast party (they'll never deny your requests to water your flowers again).

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ad19f02165ea17798702d0]||||||

+++

##Lesson #2: Don't forget the SALT##

Want a ridiculously simple yet home-run way to enhance any tomatos flavor? Just add salt. This magical rock takes its rightful place in every tomato toast recipe here. For an extra spark, step away from the shaker and cozy up to [a few new salts](http://www.epicurious.com/ingredients/the-only-three-salts-you-need-article) this summer. Flaky sea salt like Maldon is delicious on ["The Peach"](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/tomato-toast-with-peaches-mozzarella-and-mint-56389822) and ["The Classic,"](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/classic-tomato-toast-with-mayonnaise-and-chives-56389808) setting off the pure flavor of tomato like nothing else can. But dont think for a second you cant break out all those weird salts your spice rack might have accumulated: Himalayan pink salt, black lava salt, *fleur de sel*, or that crazy jar you got on vacation and are saving for a special occasion. After all, tomato season is a very special occasion all by itself.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ad17cd98d8666b6dcdb218]||||||

+++

##Lesson #3: Sometimes, you need a bit of HEAT##

While a perfectly ripe tomato is a thing of beauty (and weve included plenty of no-cook recipes in the mix that capitalize on that), dont be afraid to add heat. Roasting cherry tomatoes makes their flavor impact gigantic by drawing excess water out and caramelizing its sugars. Use them as a topping for thick-cut garlic bread (["The Texan"](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/texas-toast-with-roasted-tomatoes-and-parsley-56389818)) or make an extra-sweet version with maple syrup to top goat-cheese toasts (["The Candied"](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/maple-roasted-tomato-toast-with-goat-cheese-and-mint-56389824)).

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ad1dc498d8666b6dcdb63d]||||||

+++

##Lesson #4: Bump up the ACID##

Do you know why unripe or out-of-season tomatoes taste so bland? One, theyre predominantly water, and two, they lack the sugar and acidity that peak season tomatoes innately possess. Increase the power of that natural acidity by pairing tomatoes with citrus (See ["The Green Zebra"](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/green-tomato-toast-with-ricotta-salata-and-lemon-56389823), ["The Bloody Mary"](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/-bloody-mary-tomato-toast-with-celery-and-horseradish-56389813), or ["The Mexi-Cali"](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/avocado-toast-with-tomato-corn-salsa-56389819)) or vinegar (see ["The Panzanella"](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/panzanella-tomato-toast-with-crispy-capers-and-basil-leaves-56389826)).

[#gallery: /galleries/55ae77cc6284773353bf283c]|||
13 Amazing Ways to Make Tomato Toast
|||

section3List.hed: Meet the Tostada Party, the Make-Ahead, No-Stress Backyard Bash of Summer
section3List.dek: When a party is this simple, this delicious, and involves this much tequila, a host has no choice but to pour a drink and join in.
section3List.body:
Let's talk about *taquizas*. Everybody loves a *taquiza* (taco party). Everybody, that is, except the host.

Because the taco fillings need to stay warm. And good corn tortillas need to be eaten fresh off the griddle (they become leathery when they cool). And all of that cuts into margarita time. 

The solution: Swap out tacos for tostadas. Unlike tacos, these crispy, open-faced snacks on fried tortillas are completely make-ahead. And guests assemble their own plates, which make tostada parties perfect for stress-free summer entertaining. (And as a bonus, the crisp tortillas and shower of iceberg lettuce trigger childhood hard-shell taco memories.) 

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ad3f1498d8666b6dcdbb38]|||
Hey girl. It's tostada time.
|||

+++

My tostada parties draw inspiration from Mexico Citys Mercado Coyoacn, which boasts some of the citys best market *puestos* (food stands). When I'm there, I save the bulk of my appetite for the bustling cluster of decades-old tostada vendors, who frantically battle for business by showing off big piles of toppings, piled conically like massive party hats. There's shrimp, crab, octopus, tuna, mushrooms, cows feet, thinly-sliced steak, shredded beef *salpicn*, ground beef picadillo, chicken in sweet mole and more chicken, this time in a smoky *tinga*. Mounded on crisp-fried corn tortillas and garnished to order, the tostadas are somehow both heartier and more refreshing than tacos. Which is what makes them so perfect for a steamy afternoon in the city.

And it turns out that Mexico City's tostada culture is surprisingly easy to replicate at homethough the sheer scope of tostada options is, of course, hard to pull off. For a party, I usually stick to three or four, making sure to hit the [chicken](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/spicy-chipotle-chicken-tostadas-56389833), [beef](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/shredded-beef-tostadas-with-chiles-and-lime-56389831), and veg bases. (*[Rajas](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/tostadas-with-creamy-roasted-poblanos-and-corn-56389834)*, my go-to vegetarian option, is usually the first to go.) As in Mexico City, the toppings should be served at room temperature, not cold. (If preparing these recipes ahead of time, reheat the rajas and tinga before cooling to room temperature.)


+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ac465f2165ea177986f88f]|||
Shrimp-Salad Tostadas with Tomatoes and Cucumber
|||

+++


As for the tostadas themselves, Mexican groceries and most bigger supermarkets sell them already-fried. But frying your own is simple (just use slightly stale tortillas whenever possible). 

And dont skimp on garnishes: Offer shredded iceberg lettuce (or romaine hearts) for its juicy bite, Mexican crema (or thinned sour cream), crumbled *queso fresco*, an array of salsas, and other veggies and herbs of your choice such as sliced avocado, sliced radishes, chopped cilantro, and pickled red onion. 


+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ad076a2165ea177986fcde]|||
Peaches and Crema Paleta Pops
|||

+++


Let guests build their own, letting them know that the tostadas will be best if they start with a creamy base like guacamole or pureed black beans, pile on a lot of *tinga* (or whatever topping), and finish with as many garnishes as the tostada will hold. People can also eat the [beans](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/creamy-black-bean-spread-56389830) or [guac](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/hold-the-lime-guacamole-56389663) on the side. Or they can just stick to the [paletas](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/peaches-and-crema-paleta-pops-56389835), or the [agua frescas](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/cucumber-basil-agua-fresca-56389827) (maybeokay, definitelywith a splash of tequila). Because there are no rules when it comes to a tostada party, except one: Leave tacos out of it.

[#gallery: /galleries/55affd116284773353bf449c]||||||

section3List.hed: Why You Should Leave the Lime Out of Your Guacamole
section3List.dek: Lime is an integral part of a great guacamoleor so we thought. Turns out, American cooks put the lime in. And now it's time to take it out.
section3List.promoHed: Why You Should Never Put Lime in Your Guacamole
section3List.body:
Twenty years ago, I asked a server at Mexico Citys legendary [El Bajo](http://www.restauranteelbajio.com.mx/) if there was lime in their exceptionally rich, deep guacamole. She tsk-tsked me with her finger. No, no," she said. "Lime masks the avocado. 

In retrospect, it seems so obvious. But at the time, I, like most Americans, ceremoniously squeezed fresh lime juice into my guacamole, a finishing touch that I believed *accentuated* or *balanced* the flavors. It wasn't until I started spending time in Mexico that I found guacs that, in whatever form they tookdrizzled over empanadas, slathered as a base for ceviche tostadas, served chunky-style piled alongside thin grilled steakstasted like avocado concentrate, with only a wisp of citrus acidity, if any. 

I felt as if I had uncovered a big secret: Avocado with lime doesnt taste like a *better* avocadojust a limey one. 

> The richness of limeless guacamole can be revelatory, like French fries with mayonnaise instead of ketchup

Of course, limeless guacamole isn't a secret at all. Looking through cookbooks from some masters of Mexican cooking, I found a common thread. Diana Kennedy all but forbids it in *[The Art Of Mexican Cooking](http://www.amazon.com/The-Mexican-Cooking-Diana-Kennedy/dp/0307383253)*, saying it spoils the balance of flavors. In *[Hugo Ortega's Street Foods Of Mexico](http://www.amazon.com/Hugo-Ortegas-Street-Food-Mexico/dp/1936474735/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1432312126&sr=1-1&keywords=hugo%20ortega%27s%20street%20food%20of%20mexico)*, Ortega writes, the secret to a good guacamole is to respect the avocado flavor and not drown it in lime juice (he adds a scant 1/4 teaspoon for two large avocados). [Susana Trilling](http://www.amazon.com/Seasons-My-Heart-Culinary-Journey/dp/0345425960/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1432312179&sr=1-1&keywords=susana%20trilling) skips it in her thin Oaxaca-style guac; [Patricia Quintana](http://www.amazon.com/Taste-Mexico-Patricia-Quintana/dp/1556703260/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1432312209&sr=1-1&keywords=Patricia%20Quintana) only adds it when its accompanying a dish with no other acidic element, or conceding some Northern chefs taste for it. The guacamole in Guadalupe Riveras book about culinary life with her father Diego and Frida Kahlo, *[Fridas Fiestas](http://www.amazon.com/Fridas-Fiestas-Recipes-Reminiscences-Frida/dp/0517592355/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1432312241&sr=1-1&keywords=frieda%27s%20fiestas)*, is given punch with chipotle chiles, not citrus. And in 1917s *Los 30 Mens Del Mes*, from influential culinary academic Alejandro Pardo, theres no lime in the *huacamole*though there are roasted tomatoes. (In pre-Columbian Mexico, guacamole likely consisted of avocado mashed with wild onion, chile, and maybe tomato or tomatillocilantro and limes arrived with the Conquest.)
 
But in the 1970s, when guacamoles popularity in the US rose alongside trends like California Cuisine, none of those traditional recipes mattered. The trend was bright foods, and because sodium fears were at a peak, lime was deployed to provide flavor. Suddenly, guacamoles were citrusy (and also undersalted, which is a shame, because avocados can handle big doses of the stuff). 

This isn't to [throw shade](http://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/17/magazine/the-underground-art-of-the-insult.html) on guacamole with lime or anything. A citrusy guac is good stuff. But it's not as good as it could be. As a dip with chips, the richness of limeless guacamole can be revelatory, like French fries with mayonnaise instead of ketchup. And youre likely combining the guac with an acidic component anywaya salsa maybe, or the ubiquitous lime wedge served alongside tacos of grilled meat. Chiles and onion provide textural and flavor contrast without obscuring the avocado (which is why you should only use white onion rather than yellow or sweet onions, which muddy the flavor). And if you really need a hit of acid, tomatoes can always be thrown in. (Though this is easier done in Mexico, where vine-ripened tomatoes are more readily available. With ripe tomatoes so rare in the U.S., I generally leave them out.)

I know what you're about to ask. "But what about oxidation? While lime is touted as a way prevent avocados from browning, it takes a *lot* of lime for that to workand its generally a bad idea to transform a dishs taste for aesthetic reasons. The easy fix: Avoid oxidation altogether by making your guacamolea 5 minute process at mostright before serving. I promise, it wont last for long.


[#recipe: /recipes/556efa110f59eef70ea804b4]||||||

section5List.hed: Summer Cocktails You Can Drink All Day Long
section5List.dek: Summers most thirst-quenching cocktails all have one thing in common.
section5List.promoHed: Why You Should Drink Like a Brit This Summer
section5List.body:
Take it from British folks who sit outside in the blazing heat watching a lot of tennis. When scorching summer days strike, there's nothing you want more than an icy, fizzy, fruit-tastic Pimms Cup. You'll see folks by the dozen in crowd shots at Wimbeldon, clutching cups of what looks like fruit-spiked iced tea. It basically  so does the craving for a chilled cocktail glass filled with something light, fruity and refreshing. We know were not alone: In England during the buzzy, boozy days surrounding Wimbledon tennis, it is practically a prerequisite to sip your way through an afternoon. And there is no tipple more quenching and daytime-appropriate than an icy, fizzy, fruit-tastic Pimms Cup. 

Though the ingredients in a classic Pimms Cup are on the simpler side, a well-made one is a thing of beauty. Traditionally there is a carbonated, lemony base; Pimms No. 1 (a low-alcohol, gin-based liqueur infused with spicy, herbal notes), and a garnish of summer produce, namely perky cucumbers, fresh mint, and colorful fruit. 

Besides just nailing all of the qualities you would arguably want in a warm-weather drinkfreshness, a balance of sweetness and acidity, plus some fresh produce to nibble onthe cocktail is also in line with a current low-proof cocktail trend here in the States. The alcohol by volume is subtle enough that you can have a few in a day and still maintain decent composure into the night (if you want to). 

The best part to us, though, are the countless ways you can tinker with these all-star ingredients of Pimms, lemon and fruit to make new summer classics. We turned to some of the countrys coolest bartenders for a modern, low-proof(ish) take on drinks featuring these indispensible ingredients. 

##Use PIMMS as a cocktail BASE##

While it might seem like something youd only find in the cabinets of posh old ladies, there is plenty the average home bartender can do with a bottle of Pimms No. 1 lying around, says Julie Reiner, co-owner of [Clover Club](https://cloverclubny.com/) bar in Brooklyn and author of the new recipe book *[The Craft Cocktail Party](http://www.amazon.com/The-Craft-Cocktail-Party-Delicious/dp/1455581593)*. Because Pimms is low a.b.v., its a great ingredient for lengthening a cocktail, Reiner says. Its herbal base makes it really versatile and helps it work with almost any spirit.

In her new book, Reiner created a Pimms and Champagne-based punch that she says could be served in any season, but more importantly is an easy, festive option to make and serve in big batches for a group. Its impressive, but its so easy to make that I knew home bartenders would have a lot of success with it," Reiner says. The base of the drink can be prepped ahead of time, so when friends show up all you have to do is add the ice and bubbly. And because of its low alcohol content, you wont be getting your guests too buzzed too fast. 

If you do make this punch ahead, consider straining out the fruit thats been marinating overnight and adding fresh fruit to each glass for the prettiest presentation. As Reiner says, People drink with their eyes before they actually taste the cocktail.

[#recipe: /recipes/55b0e9c8a188eea213e626e0]|||
Pimm's Royale Punch
|||

##Pack Your Cocktail with Fruit##

Jane Danger, bartender at [The NoMad Bar](https://www.thenomadhotel.com/#!/dining/spaces/the-nomad-bar) in New York City says the ideal day drinks strike a balance of sweetness and complexity. Day drinks need to be light and refreshing, Danger says, but not too sweet, nor overly contemplative. In her namesake Berry Dangerous Fix cocktail, she uses strawberries, which have a natural balance of sugar and acidity, then introduces hints of bitterness and anise flavor with Campari and aquavit. The fruity flavors are friendly and familiar, but not one-note, so you dont get bored. This drink can keep you amused the whole afternoon.

When muddling up your own berries, pay attention to the sweetness of your berries, she advises. If theyre particularly sweet or sour, adjust your other ingredients to account for that. That can be as easy as adding a little more simple syrup, or an extra squeeze of lime.

[#recipe: /recipes/55b0eb316284773353bf45a9]|||
Berry Dangerous Fix Cocktail
|||

##Don't forget the fizzy lemon soda##

In Chattanooga, Tennessee, where temperatures frequently approach 100 degrees in the summertime, bartender Alex Jump of [Easy Bistro & Bar](http://www.easybistro.com/) says a low-alcohol cocktailespecially a sparkling versionis the best way to kick off a meal. And in those cocktails, they frequently use bitter lemon soda as a substitute for mundane bubbly water. 

"For drinks like Tom Collins or white-wine sangrias, bitter lemon soda is a great substitute for plain soda water," Jump says. Made with the pith and peel of fresh lemons and with quinine (like in tonic water), it really brightens up a drink as a mixer with gin and vodka, she adds. Her latest concoction pairs Dolin Blanc vermouth, Aperol, and bitter lemon soda in a crisp, refreshing aperitif she calls the Wild Heart. Its the perfect balance between sweet, tart and bittersomething you would want to drink on your porch.

[#recipe: /recipes/55b0ea7ca188eea213e626e9]|||
Wild Heart Cocktail
|||

section5List.hed: The Margarita-Ros Cocktail Mashup Your Summer Needs
section5List.seoTitle: The Margarita-Ros Cocktail Mashup Your Summer Needs
section5List.seoDescription: The recipe for The Mos, a margarita made with ros wine.
section5List.socialTitle: The Margarita-Ros Cocktail Mashup Your Summer Needs
section5List.body:
As soon as June hits, my drinking regimen undergoes two seismic shifts.

[#article: /articles/54c14e0ee231becc7f3db37b]||||||

First, I start making pitchers of margaritas. Mine only have three ingredients: Tequila, lime juice, and agave syrup. They're boozy, punchy, and not too sweet. 

The second shift: I break out the dry ros. 

Which got me thinking: Why can't a cocktail combine all the best parts of a margaritabracing blanco tequila, loads of citrus, and a bit of sweet sugarwith the pure summery bliss of a glass of ros?

I'm here to tell you that it can. 

Meet [The Mos](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/the-mose-56389689)it's the margarita-ros mashup I've always wanted. 

I'm always looking to work seasonal produce into my house cocktailswhether it's [rhubarb](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes-menus/the-spring-house-cocktail-with-rhubarb-gin-and-ginger-article), [arugula](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes-menus/green-vesper-vegetable-cocktail-recipes-article), or [rosemary](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/rosemary-infused-spring-cocktail-article). It's summer and not using fresh-from-the-market strawberries whenever possible should considered a legal offense. So for my Mos, rather than use agave syrup like I would in a margarita, I simply top a couple of sliced strawberries with a bit of sugar and muddle until it's dissolved into a sweet, pulpy mess. 

Next comes high-quality blanco tequila. I'm a big fan of those made by [Casa Dragones](http://casa-dragones.1-877-spirits.com/blanco), [Astral](http://www.getwineonline.com/sku31865_ASTRAL-TEQUILA-BLANCO-750ML), and [Casa Noble](http://www.astorwines.com/SearchResultsSingle.aspx?search=21561). In the shaker it goes with some fresh lemon juice (lime clashed with the delicate sweetness of the strawberries by announcing itself too loudly) and a bit of ros. 

A note on the ros: You'll want to find a dry bottle from Provence, not something fruity and sweet. (Need more info? We've [got a guide for that](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/a-complete-guide-to-drinking-rose-wine-this-summer-article).)

Shake it all together with a large ice cube (we're talking [2 inches wide](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/guide-to-cocktail-ice-shapes-article) or larger here) and pour the whole thing without straining into a rocks glass. Why no straining? Because then you'd be wasting all those delicious chunks of strawberries. And that big ice cube's criticalit almost acts as an ingredient in and of itself, gradually diluting the tequila's boozy heat over the course of the first half of the drink. 

I'm not sure why it took so long for the margarita and ros to get together like this. I'm just glad it finally happened. 

[#recipe: /recipes/5570a6b181ac1e5023671d01]||||||

section5List.dek: All you need: a blender and fresh herbs.
section5List.body:
I didn't drink sodaor any carbonated beveragesgrowing up. No Sprite. No Pepsi. Zero Cokeand, for that matter, no Coke Zero.

It wasn't because they were outlawed in my houseboth of my parents and my sister drank them. Soda just didn't appeal to me for whatever reason. That self-imposed ban made my beverage options pretty limited as a kid: Water, milk, and lemonade. 

Lemonade became my favorite early on. What kid doesn't like homemade lemonade? It's the perfectly balance between face-puckeringly tart and gentle sweetness. Even the stuff made from concentrate wasn't *that* bad. 

But recently, I set out to do something my younger self would have never dreamed possible: Upgrade lemonade.  

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55916058e308899c32d5552d]||||||

+++

My inspiration stemmed from a experience I had at [Nish Nush](http://www.nishnushnyc.com/), a modern Israeli falafel shop in downtown Manhattan. The menu offers up something called *Limonana*, a frozen beverage with Middle-Eastern origins that's part lemonade, part virgin mojito, and all delicious. I got to work in the Epicurious Test Kitchen and started playing around with how to replicate the thing. 

As it turns out, two easy steps take lemonade from nostalgic favorite to a do-anything beverage springboard: A blender and fresh mint. You can use store-bought lemonade, but it's best if you make your own.

The result is the lemonade I remember drinking growing up, but with the added soothing sweet flavor of mint. This version's suitable for kids, but I could easily see adults adding a few ounces of floral gin or jalepeo-infused tequila in order to transform 
the drink into an easy-to-make blender cocktail. 

Whatever you do to it, I promise it will ruin lemonade for you like it did for mein the best way possible.

##Frozen Mint Lemonade##

Combine the juice from __3 lemons__, __6 tablespoons sugar__, __1/2 cup water__, and about __40 fresh mint leaves__ (stems discarded) in a blender filled with ice. Pulse a few times and then blend until slushy.

section5List.hed: The Rum Cocktail That's Perfect for Summer Cookouts
section5List.dek: A mix of rich rum, fresh citrus, and our favorite seasonal fruit makes this cocktail a winner.
section5List.body:
July is the first month we truly commit to spending all of our free time outside. 

Grills are lit, swimming pools uncovered, and coolers stocked with an army of cold beers. Aside from the occasional blender cocktail or tiki drink, beer's usually my beverage of choice during the summer months thanks to its low alcohol level, ubiquity, and the limited prep work required to enjoy one. 

But one can't survive on cheap beer alonealthough some [might argue](http://www.gq.com/story/david-chang-cheap-beer) with thatsometimes you just need a cocktail. And, this year, I wanted to create a house cocktail that works just as well for an indoor dinner party as it does for outdoor barbecue sessions. 

[#article: /articles/5570b08d81ac1e5023671d6d]||||||

That's how [The Cherry Bomb](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/the-cherry-bomb-56389793) was born. 

My starting place was the classic [Whiskey Smash](http://www.bonappetit.com/recipe/classic-whiskey-smash), a simple mix of whiskey, muddled lemon, mint, and simple syrup topped with a mound of crushed ice. The drink is boozy, sure, but the crushed ice and sugary lemon juice mixture that forms the base of the drink makes it surprisingly refreshing. 

I opted to swap out whiskey for dark rumboth are potent brown spirits, but rum's underlying sweetness makes for a cocktail I can enjoy more than one of during an afternoon by the pool. From there, I added lime to the usual muddled lemon found in a smash, the bright acidic flavor helping to balance out a bit of the sweetness that rum brings to the table. (It's the same thinking behind why I [put the stuff on top of my eggs](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/eggs-acid-vinegar-lime-juice-article).)

But the real defining characteristic of The Cherry Bomb are the fresh cherries that make their way into the bottom of the cocktail shaker. Beautiful cherries are available at seemingly every turn this time of year, an embarrassment of ruby riches at local grocery stores and farmer's markets. Here, they lend a great color and, depending on what type of fresh cherries you've got on hand, a tart, sweet, or sour flavor.

Mix all that together, pour it in an Old Fashioned glass, and pile the thing high with crushed ice. Be prepared for a dangerously drinkable cocktailjust try to remember that, yes, there's actually alcohol in it. 

Just don't blame me if you give up on your summer beer regimen forever. 

[#recipe: /recipes/5593fe9de308899c32d5649f]||||||

section4List.hed: The Best Bar Cookies for Barbecues and Cookouts
section4List.dek: Three hand-held desserts that will be the star of your barbecue.
section4List.promoHed: 3 Secrets to the Best Bar Cookies Ever
section4List.body:
If you've got a summer baking problem, bar cookies have the solution. Need an easy dessert for a barbecue? Bar cookies. Got fruit but intimidated by pie? Bar cookies. Don't want to show up empty-handed to that cookout? Bar cookies. 

Yes, bar cookies are always there when you need them. But perhaps because that tray of brownies is so perfect for a backyard barbecue, and those blondies are so easy to whip up for that bake sale,  we tend to see take them for granted, seeing them as the dependable fallbackthe understudy, never the star. 

That ends now. Fact is, these layered, chewy treats *can* be the star of the potluck. It just take one or two little tweaks. 

##Try a new, nuttier flour##

Regular all-purpose flour might be standard in baking, but swapping out some of that flour for other grains can give bar cookies magical dimension and depth. Buckwheat is a great one to try: It's actually not wheat or even a grain at all, but rather a fruit seed related to rhubarb. That might explain buckwheat's magical affinity for the strawberries in this filling. The crumbly buckwheat crust and topping combines with a filling of fresh strawberries and strawberry jam to make a bar that tastes like a handheld fruit crumble. 

[#recipe: /recipes/55ad03c898d8666b6dcdae55]|||
Strawberry Buckwheat Bars
|||

##Have fun with your toppings##

The butterscotch sweetness of blondies is great on its own, but they're also the ultimate blank canvas, just begging to be embellished with anything crunchy, nutty, and sweet. Case in point: Peanutty caramel corn, which embeds itself into the top of the blondies as they bake, forming what essentially amounts to a chewy, rich Cracker Jack bar. Only with more peanuts. Because [crunch](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-make-anything-crunchy-article).

[#recipe: /recipes/55ad05de2165ea177986fcd7]|||
Caramel Corn Blondies
|||

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ac542c2165ea177986fac2]|||
Doesn't every lime bar cookie need a luscious berry glaze?
|||

+++

##Add a killer glaze##

A blizzard of confectioners sugar isnt the only way to top a tray of creamy lime bars. A sheen of sweet-tart blueberry glaze is just as good-looking (and adds a lot more flavor). It couldnt be simpler to makejust pour the glaze over the top, tilt the pan around so it covers the whole tray, and let it set. Just make sure not to stack the cut barsyou wouldn't want to mess up that glorious glaze, would you?

[#recipe: /recipes/55ad035798d8666b6dcdae35]|||
Lime Cornmeal Bars with Blueberry Glaze
|||

section4List.hed: How to Make Lemon Bars Even Better
section4List.dek: Turn them pink with a splash of tangy raspberry pure.
section4List.promoHed: How to Make Lemon Bars Even Better
section4List.seoTitle: How to Make Lemon Bars Even Better
section4List.seoDescription: Turn them pink with a splash of tangy raspberry pure.
section4List.socialTitle: How to Make Lemon Bars Even Better
section4List.body:
What can make the tang of lemon bars better? Pinkas in pink lemonadeis what, especially when that color comes in the form of a bright splash of raspberry pure.

[#article: /articles/54d8d9bb3102fb740d182c5c]||||||

Although lemon bars are great year round, during the hot, sticky summer months, their cool, bright, tangy flavor particularly appeals to me. And yes, that yellow color is classic. But I'm all about challenging classic constructs around here ([S'mores 2.0 anyone?](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-we-turned-s-mores-into-a-cookie-recipe-camping-article)). So the lemon bar was due for an upgrade.

Although our first batch, made with straight raspberry pure, was delicious, the color was a tad muted. "If you're going to go pink, they should pop," said Editor David Tamarkin.

So I found a recipe that used beet pure for that shout of color, but wasn't interested in adding such vegetal flavor. Instead, I went with the deep, dark color of pomegranate juice. The results: a purply-pink, brightly tart filling that pleased even our pickiest lemon bar lover.

These guys also have a tender, buttery crust, thanks to a combo of confectioner's sugar and butter. The raspberry adds a touch of sweetness to the filling, which is still nice and citrusy thanks to a good dose of lemon juice. 

If you'd prefer less tartness, increase the amount of raspberry. Ultimately, the color will depend on the ripeness and color of your berries; bright red ones will produce a richer color (and flavor). 

So make a big batch and for the love of summer, eat them outside.

[#recipe: /recipes/5593fdfae308899c32d5649d]||||||

fields.title: Raspberry Lemon Bars- HERO
fields.credit: Photo by Chelsea Kyle, food styling by Katherine Sacks

section2List.hed: How to Make Ribs That Taste Like Real Barbecue
section2List.promoHed: How I Stopped Messing Up My Barbecue Ribs
section2List.body:
Close your eyes. Picture a plate piled high with barbecue. You're probably seeing racks of glossy, burnished ribs. After all, they're the obsession of competitive pitmasters and you'll find them on the menu of every barbecue place across the country.

Until recently, though, I could care less about barbecue ribs. Most that Ive encountered are basically ketchup-glazed meat sticks, more bone than meat, and either too dry and chewy or a wet, stringy mess. At home, I never bothered cooking them, either. Many recipes call for long marinades, frustrating membrane-removal, a summertime-unfriendly combination of oven roasting and grilling, and sugary sauces that overwhelm the finished product (and require a quick shower between bites). For me, a pork butt or brisket offered way more pleasure for the pain.

But then I wrote [a book about barbecue](http://www.amazon.com/Feeding-Fire-Strategies-Barbecue-Grilling/dp/1579655572) with Joe Carroll, the self-taught live-fire guru behind Brooklyns [Fette Sau](http://www.fettesaubbq.com/) and [St. Anselm](http://www.yelp.com/biz/st-anselm-brooklyn) restaurants. Joes barbecue ribs changed my outlook on the cut forever. Among other things, he taught me that I dont need a proper smoker to cook them (my grill will do), that a simple dry rub is all I need to yield tender, smoke-imbued meat veneered with a crispy, chewy bark, and that one recipe can be applied to all kinds of ribs, from classic pork to extra-juicy beef and flavorful lamb. And that sauce is not only optional, but usually unnecessary. 

Today, Im a ribs convert. And, by following these few tips, you'll become one, too.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55a6b7bf98d8666b6dcd92a7]|||
Lamb and St. Louis pork ribs on the grill. Or is it a smoker?
|||

+++

## #1: Turn your grill into a smoker.##
If you own a dedicated smoker (hopefully a charcoal- or wood-fired one), use it! But if you dont, a standard kettle grill works just as well. Start by filling a [chimney starter](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/why-you-should-buy-a-chimney-starter-for-your-grill-article) about halfway with hardwood charcoal and light it. When the coals are ready, scatter them on one side of the lower grill grate (over the bottom air vent if your grill has one) and place a disposable aluminum tray on the other to catch drippings. Drop a few chunks of hardwood over the coals, or top them with a foil packet filled with a handful of water-soaked woodchips. Add the top grate and position your ribs over the drip pan. 

Cover the grill, placing the air vents over the meat. Open both sets of vents about halfway and start smoking. Monitor the grill temperature with a thermometer (200-225F is your ideal range), adding a couple pieces of unlit charcoal and opening/closing the vents as needed to stay in this zone. If smoke stops billowing out of the top air vent, add more wood chunks or chips as needed. 
 
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55a6b8042165ea177986ded4]|||
The backyard barbecue dream: A plate of ribs (and maybe a little slaw alongside) Clockwise from the top: Beef short ribs, lamb ribs, and St. Louis-style spareribs.
|||

+++

## #2: Go beyond baby backs.##

Theres nothing wrong with baby back ribs (aka loin back ribs), but there are better options if you prefer meat and flavor over gnawing on a bone. My preferred cut from the pig is the St. Louis-style sparerib. Spareribs are longer, meatier and fattier than baby backs, and their rectangular shape helps you get a more consistent texture than the smaller baby-back neighbors. Many barbecue spareribs recipes will ask you to remove the membrane from the underside of the ribs before cooking. I dont see the point, unless youre entering your ribs in a barbecue competition: its a pain to remove, theres barely any meat on that side of the bone, and the membrane adds a bit of extra structure to the rack, which makes it easier to move the rack around on the grill.

Lamb and beef spareribs are also superb and can be cooked exactly the same way as their pork counterpart. But my favorite beef rib is the short rib: The same cut youre used to braising turns into incredible barbecue when smoked, with brisket-like flavor and texture. And no one will forget the moment a jumbo-sized rack of short ribs hits the table.  

No matter what rib youre smoking, cook it to texture, not temperature. Proper barbecue rib meat shouldnt be falling-off-the-bone tender; it should tear easily from the bone when you tug on it but still retain some chew (think steak, not pot roast). When it doubt, tear off a piece of meat and eat it; your mouth will tell you when your ribs are done.

[#recipe: /recipes/55b0e604a188eea213e626c5]|||
All-Purpose Barbecue Ribs
|||

## #3: Use the same rub for everything.##

At Fette Sau, Joe uses one dry rub for everything that goes into the smoker. And its a simple rub at that: salt, pepper, brown sugar, a few spices, and one secret ingredient: ground espresso beans. They give a bitter roasted flavor that complements the malty sweetness of the sugar (like milk and sugar are to coffee, he likes to say). 

You can follow Fette Saus dry rub recipe to the letterone batch should last you all summerbut I encourage you to develop your own. Adding your favorite spices or tweaking the ratio of salt and sugar is the easiest way to create a signature barbecue flavor. 

[#recipe: /recipes/55b0e7116284773353bf4580]|||
Fette Sau Dry Rub
|||

## #4: Use sauce sparingly (or not at all).##
Unfortunately, sauce is the very definition of barbecue for many people, who think that coating any piece of meat with shiny, sweet-spicy condiment magically turns it into cue. And too much great smoked meat is ruined by a smothering of sauce before the first bite can be taken. This is a matter of personal preference, but I rarely need sauce with my ribs these days. If dry-rubbed and properly smoked, the meat speaks for itself. 

However, should you desire sauce with your ribs, save it for the plate. The beauty of dry barbecuethat is, dry-rubbed meat thats cooked without any bastingis the resulting layer of bark that forms on the surface. This dark, chewy, intensely flavored crust is the reason I love barbecue. If sauce is a must, then choose one that wont overpower the meat, such as the vinegar sauce below, which has enough acidity to add brightness to pork ribs and enough depth to stand up to beef or lamb. Dont want to make your own? Enhance a bottled sauce by tweaking the acidity and heat levels with vinegar and hot sauce, or add some savory depth with Worcestershire sauce or drippings left over from the those beautiful ribs. 

[#recipe: /recipes/55b0e69ba188eea213e626cf]|||
Vinegar Sauce
|||

section2List.hed: Why You Should Buy a Chimney Starter for Your Grill
section2List.dek: Starting a charcoal grill doesn't have to be a pain.
section2List.promoHed: The Best $15 You Can Spend on Summer Grilling
section2List.body:
You've just returned home from the butcher store with a thick-cut, bone-in ribeye steak with a level of marbling that you didn't even think was possible. The weather outside is something to behold. The beer is ice cold. In other words, all that's left to do is set up your charcoal grill and get grilling. 

[#article: /articles/55799be574cbe9ed7c20a314]||||||

But then reality sets in. If you're anything like me, you inevitably end up spending far too long futzing with that all-natural, lump hardwood charcoal that adds great flavor, but never seems to want to light without a few MacGyver-esque tricks.  

Good news: The secret to making this process infinitely easier costs just $15 and weighs about two pounds. Meet the [chimney starter](http://www.amazon.com/Weber-7416-Rapidfire-Chimney-Starter/dp/B000WEOQV8). 

This simple piece of cylindrical gear is nothing fancy or new, it has been around for years, and it's sure to be the most lo-fi part of your grilling set-up. When I discovered their mystical, charcoal-lighting powers a decade into my amateur grilling career, I vowed to never light a fire without one ever again.

##How it Works##

Simply grab a few pieces of newspaper or any other flammable paper, crumple them up, and stuff the wadded up paper into the circular wire rack at the bottom. Next, fill the chimney with charcoal and light the newspaper with matches or a grill fluid lighter. 

Then you just sit back, relax, and watch the magic happen, as the principles of thermodynamics kick in and slowly distribute heat up through the stack of charcoal. After about 20 minutes, the charcoal will glow with heat and be covered in a thin layer of white ashthat's how you know they're ready to dump into the base of your kettle grill.

And that it'sperfect charcoal, every time.

section2List.hed: How to Make a Better Coleslaw
section2List.dek: Step one: Start thinking beyond cabbage.
section2List.promoHed: How to Make a Better Coleslaw
section2List.body:
At most [summer cookouts](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/summer-100-simple-weeknight-recipes-menus-pie-package), coleslaw means one thing: shredded, raw cabbagesometimes green, sometimes redmixed with mayonnaise. Sometimes a little carrot, too. 

We call it coleslaw. But is that all coleslaw is? Must there be cabbage? Must there be mayo?

The answer is in the definition of coleslaw, which I found in the [*Food Lover's Companion*](http://www.amazon.com/The-New-Food-Lovers-Companion/dp/0764135775/):

"Coleslaw is a salad of shredded red of white cabbage mixed with mayonnaise, vinaigrette, or other type of dressing. Other ingredients, such as chopped onion, celery, sweet green or red pepper, pickles, bacon or herbs may be added. There are probably as many variations of coleslaw as there are cooks."

That last line is key. Yes, cabbage is classic. Yes, mayonnaise is delicious. And yes, coleslaw is typically raw. But coleslaw can be so much more. I know, because I spent a few days in Epi's Test Kitchen creating recipes that prove that if it's crunchy, if it's tangy, if it's delicious alongside grilled chicken, burgers, and barbecue, then it's slaw.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ad0fc52165ea177986fe88]|||
Mint, miso, and coconut are just a few of the delicious things that you can toss with slaw.
|||

+++

##Swap Out The Cabbage##
I'll say it again: coleslaw does not equal cabbage. Really, any thinly sliced, julienned, or grated vegetable that provides a snappy crunch will work brilliantly. This means everything from fennel to Brussels sprouts to [jicama](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/white-balsamic-jicama-slaw-358170) is fair game.

In this coleslaw, I've combined three non-cabbage vegetablescrunchy carrots, earthy yellow beets, and tart applein that classic, creamy slaw dressing (though mine includes yogurt, which gives it a tangy kick). A sprinkling of caraway adds a nutty touch, giving this slaw its own distinct flavor.

[#recipe: /recipes/55acfdfb98d8666b6dcdad8e]|||
Carrot, Yellow Beet, and Apple Slaw with Caraway Seed Dressing
|||


##Kick Out The Mayonnaise##
Once you've moved beyond the cabbage, it's time to graduate from the mayo dressing. Many Southern slaws [have a vinegar-based dressing instead](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/north-carolina-style-coleslaw-242392), creating a tangy dressing that becomes a tart relief when paired with sweet and spicy barbecue.

Sounds good, right? But you don't need to stop at just plain vinegar. For this slaw, I added the Asian flavors of white miso, toasted sesame oil, and ginger to the vinaigrette, along with a large handful of chopped mint, cilantro, and Thai basil. And instead of cabbage, I went with another member of the [crucifer family](http://www.epicurious.com/ingredients/how-to-buy-store-and-eat-your-broccoli-article): Broccoli, which has a robust flavor that stands up to the intense flavors in the dressing.

[#recipe: /recipes/55acfd7198d8666b6dcdad8c]|||
Broccoli Slaw with Miso-Ginger Dressing
|||

##Cook the Cabbage##
I know, I know. You probably think the most fundamental of the coleslaw tenets is using raw vegetables. But as long as the vegetables keep their crunch, they're fair game for slaw. In this recipe, I've gone back to good old-fashioned cabbage, but I've pickled it, then grilled it, for a combination of bright, tangy flavor and summery smoke.

[#recipe: /recipes/55ad014698d8666b6dcdadf7]|||
Tangy Grilled-Cabbage Slaw with Raisins and Walnuts
|||

section2List.hed: The Do-Everything Grill-Smoker-Oven You Need to Own
section2List.body:
I've long been obsessed with the idea of cooking outdoors: The freshly-cut grass under my feat, sun beating down, cold beer in hand, and large cuts of protein showered in kosher salt and cracked black pepper thrown on the grill. 

For years, I worshipped at the altar of the classic Weber kettle grill. Its simple, utilitarian design makes using it nearly foolproof. Plus, at just under a hundred bucks, it's extremely affordable. But, at a certain point in my home grilling career, I wanted more. 

I wanted something that stayed hotter longer. I wanted something that could easily function as a smoker. (Yes, [it's possible](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-turn-your-kettle-grill-into-a-smoker-feeding-the-fire-joe-carroll-fette-sau-article) to turn my trusty Weber into a smoker, but it's not the most convenient solution.) It's around that time I discovered the [Big Green Egg](http://www.biggreenegg.com/), a ceramic cooker that's functionally a grill, smoker, and outdoor oven all at the same time. 

[#article: /articles/555e4a06100d9bda6d822337]||||||

Suddenly, I started seeing the thing absolutely everywhere: It turns out a friend's parents have one and love it. They're incredibly popular with chefs as both a reliable product and something aesthetically pleasing that doesn't look out of place in the context of their restaurant. The thing even photographs so well it's a favorite of the Instagram community.

So, I found a friend who owns one and spent some time using it. I was an instant convert. 

The biggest advantage of the Big Green Eggand other ceramic cookers like itis the ability to precisely maintain temperature. That's accomplished by two openings on the top and bottom of the vessel that allow you to control the amount of oxygenand, indirectly, the resulting temperaturethat flows through it while cooking. The egg's ceramic build helps maintain that heat for longer, as well. That means you'll have to reload the charcoal chimney less often, leaving more time for everything else on your [cooking, drinking, snacking, and baking agenda](http://www.epicurious.com/holidays-events/fourth-of-july-recipes-menus-cocktails-pie-package).

No, they're not cheapthe smallest model will set you back $400, while the largest one goes for over $1100. But it's also three devices in one: Grill, smoker, and oven. 

Want to use the egg as an oven? No problem. Just toss a [simple attachment](http://www.biggreenegg.com/eggcessories/plate-setters-baking-stones/plate-setter/) on the thing and you've created a barrier between those flames licking up through the grates and that [pork shoulder](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/slow-roasted-pork-shoulder-with-mustard-and-sage-51224010), [chicken](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/garlic-and-herb-spatchcock-grilled-chicken-56389623), or [whole fish](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/whole-fish-baked-in-sea-salt-241114) you're looking to cook outdoors. 

Pivoting to a smoker is easy once you have that set upsimply add your wood chips and lower the temperature for tender [smoked brisket](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/texas-style-smoked-brisket-51175220) or [pork ribs](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/smoked-baby-back-ribs-with-hoisin-honey-glaze-105305). 

And while there are other ceramic grills on the market[the model made by Primo](http://www.amazon.com/Primo-Ceramic-Kamado-Charcoal-Smoker/dp/B004INGDF6) is a popular onenone have the versatility of size that the Big Green Egg does. The eggs come in seven different sizes, ranging from 10 inches in grill-able diameter to 29 inches. For some perspective: the largest model is capable of cooking 16 whole chickens at once.

Now, if you'll excuse me, I've got a perfectly cooked brisket to marvel at.

section2List.hed: Why You Should Grill Your Burgers in a Cast Iron Skillet
section2List.dek: Real talk: Don't put them directly on the grates.
section2List.promoHed: Why You Should Grill Your Burgers in a Cast Iron Skillet
section2List.body:
Grilled burgers are never good. There. I said it.

Don't get me wrongthey're *absolutely* fun to make in the summer months. I love tossing thin, hand-formed patties on the grill with a mess of vegetables, hot dogs, and sauced-up chicken wings. 

But those burgers on the grill are in no way great burgers. Too often they're dry and overly charred, and any trace of beefy flavor has been replaced by what can only be described as "grill." (Or worse, if you happen to end up at a cookout with someone who uses lighter fluid on their charcoal.)

This isn't anybody's fault per seit's an inherent problem with that grill. The issue with cooking burgers atop the grates of a blazing charcoal grill is that burgers are meant to be cooked in their own fat. With a grill, all of those precious, fatty juices drip down to the fire below, causing the flareups that create that horrible, burnt crust. Got a burger with a higher fat content? Get ready for bigger flareups.

Luckily, we're in the business of solutions here at Epicurious. And as with so many other cooking conundrums, the answer lies in a cast iron skillet. 

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/555f47e1644d45515b75a1b9]||||||

+++

Yes, what you're looking at in that photo is a cast iron skillet set right on a grill. Yes, those are burgers in that skillet. And yes, this is our solution.

Cast iron works on the grill just like it does on your kitchen's stovetop: Place it directly on your grill's grates and let it get ripping hot. Pour a tablespoon or two of a neutral oil into the skillet and wait until it starts smoking. Then place your patties in the skilletmake sure things don't get too crowdedand step away from the grill and let your burgers cook, covering the grill (with the top vent open) for a minute or two during the process to let the patties pick up some smokiness. 

Soon your burgers will be cooking away in all of their own juices. 

Will there be flare-ups? No. 

Will there be blackened edges to the burgers? No. 

Will there be juicy, smoky burgers with that idyllic, rich brown crust we all chase after? Yes.

section2List.hed: How to Tell If Your Steak Is Cooked Without a Thermometer
section2List.dek: There's an obvious trick to determining when that steak on the grill is perfect. The only problem? People have been telling you *not* to do this for years.
section2List.promoHed: The Obvious Trick to Knowing When Your Steak Is Done
section2List.body:
My tiny New York City apartment doesn't have any outdoor space, so when I recently spent some time in a rental house in Florida, I cooked on the grill. 

A lot. 

Like, for every meal.  

One night, when I was grilling steak, I ran into the kitchen to grab an instant-read digital thermometer. But the rental house kitchen snubbed methere was no thermometer to be found. Without it, I was stumped. How was I going to determine when my steaks were ready to come off the grill?

[#article: /articles/5567955450e46c5c01e99752]||||||

The internet is full of tricks for figuring out when a steak is done. The most common one is the "[hand test](http://lifehacker.com/267250/determine-the-doneness-of-a-steak)," which alleges that various parts of your hand feel the way a steak does when it's rare, medium-rare, and so forth. But to be honest, that just never works for me. 

James Beard Award-winning chef and grilling expert Chris Schlesinger believes that the hand test is "really meant for restaurant chefs, since they're cooking one steak after another and have a better sense of what the meat should feel like at a certain doneness. For the home cook, it's really not practical."

What does he suggest? To cut into the meat. 

Yes, you read that right. 

"Just nick the meat in a spot that's not too noticeable and peak inside. It's the way I check steak when I grill at home," says Schlesinger. 

Cutting into a steak has long been considered a big no-no because of the risk of losing the steak's precious juice. But Schlesinger firmly believes that the loss in negligible. Sure, you might lose a bit of juice from the cells you cut into. But that will in no way ruin your steak. 

What *will* ruin your steak is if you keep it on the grill until it's exactly where you want it. You need to remove the meat from the grill one stage *before* your preferred doneness. "Steaks will always continue to cook as they rest, and the internal temps will raise another 5 to 10 degrees depending on thickness," says Rhoda Boone, Epi's Food Editor. So if you like your steak cooked to medium, take it off the grill when it looks medium rare inside. Which you'll know, of coursebecause you've cut into the steak to find out.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a41ea96529d92b2c0072f9]|||
Salt-And-Pepper Steak
|||

section2List.hed: Potato Salad Problems (And How to Fix Them)
section2List.dek: Troubleshooting all your potato salad hangups.
section2List.seoTitle: How to Fix Potato Salad Problems
section2List.seoDescription: Consider your potato salad problems solved.
section2List.socialTitle: Potato Salad Problems (And How to Fix Them)
section2List.socialDescription: Consider your potato salad problems solved.
section2List.body:
Of all of the foods [you should make yourself](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/foods-to-stop-buying-making-grocery-store-article), potato salad is screaming for some DIY magic. The stuff in the tub at the store is just scary, and the deli counter's potato salad sits soaked in so much mayo, you might think you're eating soup, not salad.

And it's summer, which is no time for soup.

But the path to good, homemade potato salad is not always an easy one. Overcooked potatoes might turn your salad into a mash, or a thick, uninteresting salad dressing may leave your salad bland. You may even encounter the dreaded undercooked tuber, ruining an otherwise perfectly good salad. Whatever your gripe, we've got a fix for it.

####Problem: Bland Potatoes####
__Solution: Season Your Water With Salt and Herbs__

Before bringing your potatoes to a boil, add salt and sprigs of parsley to the stockpot of cold water. This step brings so many extra opportunities for flavor infusion in the potatoesadd garlic if you like, or a tablespoon of vinegar to help the potatoes get even punchier.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4230719925f464b379402]||||||

####Problem: Dressing That Just Doesn't Work####
__Solution: Toss Your Taters While They're Hot__

When you toss warm potatoes in dressing, they'll absorb some of the dressing, producing a sort of magical cohesion and better flavor all around. For oil-based salads, toss the potatoes with dressing and vinaigrette when the potatoes are hot. If using a mayo-based dressing, stir in the potatoes when theyre warm, not hotyou don't want to break the mayo.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a426fe19925f464b37c133]||||||

####Problem: Soggy Potato Texture####
__Solution: Smart Shopping and a Steam__

So much of your final potato salad's texture is based on potato choice. A waxy potato has a great texture and keeps its shape when cooked. Use small baby red potatoes, fingerlings, or baby new potatoes. They won't break up too much while you're mixing, keeping most of your salad intact. Some of these have such soft skins, they dont even require peeling.

If your waxy potatoes are still soggy, try steaming them in a basket. You wont get the same kind of flavorful potato that a seasoned boiling creates, but youll be able to avoid overcooking easier.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a42e256529d92b2c011fff]||||||

####Problem: Overly Heavy Dressing####
__Solution: Brighten Up Your Seasonings__

Use [pickle juice](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/eggy-potato-salad-with-pickles-395434), [buttermilk](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/potato-salad-with-buttermilk-dressing-103774), and additional vinegar to freshen up a heavy dressing. A [squeeze of lemon never hurt](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/lemony-potato-salad-354231), either. If you have fresh herbs or scallion greens around, chop and toss them into the potato salad for some additional crunch and call it [a green goddess](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/green-goddess-potato-salad-238694) potato salad. 

And while we're on the topic of lighter dressings, let's just think outside of mayo altogether. German potato salads, tossed in a vinegar-laced dressing, are mouth-puckering, bacon-crusted, and way too underrated. Rhoda Boone, our Food Editor, loves a warm [bacon-mustard vinaigrette](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/mashed-root-vegetables-with-bacon-vinaigrette-51124250) on the potatoes. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a41ead19925f464b377067]||||||

####Problem: Deadly Mayonnaise####
__Solution: Put Your Salad on Ice__

And the biggest question: how long can a potato salad sit out before getting bad? Around four hours unrefrigerated (and out of the sun) is the max for mayo-based saladsat that point, it's been in the "danger zone" between 40F and 140F for too long. To keep potato salad safer longer, fill a larger bowl with ice for nesting the potato salad bowl, and always keep it out of direct light.

fields.title: 366411 fingerling-potato-salad
fields.credit: Photo by Ditte Isager

section2List.hed: How to Turn Your Kettle Grill into a Smoker
section2List.promoHed: How to Turn Your Kettle Grill into a Smoker
section2List.body:
Summer was made for grilling. Red-hot charcoal, hot dogs, burgers, the obligatory limp, grilled eggplant (hey, some of our best friends are vegetarian). 

But what about true *barbecue*. The type of slow and low cooking that's characterized by billowing plumes of smoke at 9-hour cook times. How do we do *that* at home?

In his new book *[Feeding the Fire](http://www.amazon.com/Feeding-Fire-Strategies-Barbecue-Grilling-ebook/dp/B00N2A6HO8/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1432235479&sr=1-1&keywords=feeding%20the%20fire)*, NYC chef and restaurateur Joe Carroll and writer Nick Fauchald break down the separate and often misunderstood art forms of barbecue and grilling. While there are plenty of great tips for those looking to get their grill on, it's Carroll's smoking advice we really wanted. After all, the man produces award-winning 'cue at his smoked meat meccas in Brooklyn and Philadelphia, [Fette Sau](http://www.fettesaubbq.com/). 

That's great and all, but there's one problem: Like a lot of people, we don't have a smoker. 

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/555e25e8100d9bda6d8220aa]||||||

+++

Luckily, Carroll's book gives us the blueprint for smoking in something that most people already have and anyone can [buy for less than $100](http://www.amazon.com/Weber-741001-Silver-One-Touch-22-Inch/dp/B00004RALU)a simple charcoal kettle grill.

The biggest hurdle to summertime smoking for most home cooks is not having a dedicated smokerthey're expensive, bulky, and yet another piece of cooking equipment. But they seem especially redundant if you already have a perfectly acceptable charcoal kettle grill sitting around.   Well, good news: "Kettle grills make pretty good smokers," says Carroll. You just need a few pointers on how to set them up for barbecue success.

##Turn your kettle grill into a smoker##
It's easy. First, be sure to thoroughly clean out all ash and debris from the bottom of the grill before you do anything. From there, use a [chimney starter](http://www.amazon.com/Weber-7416-Rapidfire-Chimney-Starter/dp/B000WEOQV8) to heat up your [hardwood lump charcoal](http://www.webstaurantstore.com/royal-oak-natural-wood-lump-charcoal-8-kg-bag/688CLUMP8K.html?utm_source=amazon-pads&utm_medium=cpc&utm_term=688CLUMP8K) just as you would if were grilling. Once they're ready, remove the grate and dump the charcoal one side of the grill and place a disposable aluminum tray on the other. Place a few hardwood chunks (more on that in a second) over the coals, replace the grate, and place your meat on the grill over the pan. 

Using a [grill thermometer](http://www.amazon.com/bbq-factory-CHARCOAL-SMOKER-THERMOMETER/dp/B008N5JMEY/ref=zg_bs_3563990011_7), monitor the heat of your DIY smokeryou want to stay between 200F and 225F. If things get too hot, close the top vent. On the other hand, if the temperature drops too low, add a few pieces of unlit hardwood charcoal. 

(The only problem with using your kettle grill as a smoker is that you have to remove the top of it to add more charcoal and wood, which will cause smoke and heat to escape. This means your meat might take a bit longer to smoke, but shouldn't be too much of an issue if you work quickly and efficiently.)

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/555e25e8644d45515b759d10]||||||

+++

SCORE WOOD CHIPS FOR MORE FLAVOR
------------------
[Wood chips](http://www.amazon.com/s/ref=sr_nr_n_2?fst=as%3Aoff&rh=n%3A2972638011%2Cp_4%3AWeber%2Cn%3A%213238155011%2Cn%3A553760%2Cn%3A13299251%2Cn%3A9001145011%2Cn%3A9001148011&bbn=9001145011&ie=UTF8&qid=1432239454&rnid=9001145011), it turns out, are an incredibly important part of the smoking universe. Charcoal will give your food smokiness, but wood adds an extra layer of depth. But you'll want to choose your wood wisely. For example, while mesquite might be the most widely available, its aggressive, bitter flavor might not be exactly what you're looking for. 

Instead, look to milder smoking woods: Consider cherry or apple if you want to impart a gentle sweetness; maple and pecan for a medium amount of smoky essence; and woods like hickory, oak, and walnut for an unmistakable pungent smokiness (just use those woods in smaller amounts).

MAKE A KILLER SPICE RUB
-----------------------
Want to define your your own personal style of 'cue? The best place to start is with your spice rub. Carroll bases most of his menu on his house blend. "We use this rub on just about everything that we smoke," writes Carroll. His version uses dark brown sugar, salt, ground espresso, black pepper, garlic powder, cinnamon, cumin, and cayenneand works great as a starting point point for your own. Want a spicier smoked meat? Up the amount of cayenne and cut down on the sugar. Looking to add a Cajun or North African bent to your brisket? Check out more ideas [right here](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-make-spice-blends-article). 

DON'T SKIP THE BARBECUE CHICKEN
-------------------------------------
So you've hacked your kettle grill into a smoker, made your own house spice rub, and bought some fancy new wood chips. Now it's time to smoke something. We love Carroll's dead-simple dry rub-brined chicken. "Barbecue chicken is so common that we often overlook it," writes Carroll. "But when done well, it's one of my very favorites." That dry rub you concocted? It's going flavor the chicken in the form of a simple brine, which will keep things juicy. No time for a 4- to 8-hour brine? Just coat the chicken in the stuff, toss it on the smoker, and call it a day. Either way, you can't lose.  

[#recipe: /recipes/555ddcd4644d45515b759349]||||||

section2List.dek: It's not because it makes it sweeter.
section2List.promoHed: The Crazy Ingredient That Makes Steaks More Tender
section2List.body:
So you're ready for summer grilling. You've purchased [the perfect grill](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/big-green-egg-grill-oven-smoker-article), and you've procured the [latest, greatest cuts of steak](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/the-new-butcher-s-steaks-are-cheap-flavorful-and-ready-for-the-grill-article). 

[#article: /articles/5567955450e46c5c01e99752]||||||

Cut to you throwing that glorious piece of meat onto a blazing hot grill, all of your loved ones looking on in anticipation. A few minutes later, the steak is pulled off the grill. You slice into the meat's thick crust to reveal perfectly medium-rare flesh. 

The only problem? When you actually eat the steak you realize it's, well, *chewy*. 

And why? Because you forgot the sugar. 

It may seem counterintuitive to make like Mary Poppins and add a spoonful of the sweet stuff to your meat. But you don't add sugar for its flavoryou add it for its effect on texture. Some of the most popular cuts of beef (skirt steak, flank steak) are tough and chewy unless exposed to sugar, which is a natural tenderizer. So how do you get the sugar onto the steak? Two ways.

THROW TOGETHER A QUICK RUB
----------

Make a large batch of this easy-to-remember rub to use on beef, poultry, or vegetables: Combine 4 parts salt, 3 parts brown sugar, 2 parts sweet paprika, and 1 part cayenne pepper. It sounds like a lot of sugar, but it's not there just to tenderizeit also assists in giving your steak a caramelized crust. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a420726529d92b2c0080cb]||||||

WHIP UP A SIMPLE MARINADE
-------------------------

If you've got extra time on your hands, tenderize whatever you're cooking with an easy marinade. Combine brown sugar with other flavorful ingredients such as cilantro, olive oil, soy sauce, garlic, even a few jalapeos, if you've got some. The marinade found in this recipe for Korean steak tacos is a good place to start; let the meat marinate for at least 20 minutes, and up to 24 hours.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a421396529d92b2c00871c]||||||
section2List.socialTitle: How Sugar Makes A Steak Better
section2List.seoTitle: How Sugar Can Make A Steak More Tender
